overview: Carer's Allowance can help if you look after someone who needs to be cared for - what you'll get, eligibility, apply, claim for DS700
title: Carer's Allowance

table.body:
Carer's Allowance is £58.45 a week to help you look after someone with substantial caring needs. 

You don't have to be related to, or live with, the person you care for.

You need to be aged 16 or over and spend at least 35 hours a week caring for them.

Carer's Allowance can affect your other [benefits](carers-allowance/further-information "Effect on other benefits").

^ If you need help paying for the care you need - apply for [Attendance Allowance](/attendance-allowance "Attendance Allowance").^
table.title: Overview

table.body:
You can get £58.45 a week Carer's Allowance. 

Carer's Allowance can affect your [benefits](/carers-allowance/further-information) or those of the person you care for.

^Use the [benefits adviser](/benefits-adviser "Benefits adviser") to work out how much you can get.^  			

##How you're paid

You can choose to be paid either weekly in advance, or every 4 or 13 weeks. 

All benefits, pensions and allowances are paid [into an account](/how-to-have-your-benefits-paid "how to have your benefits paid"), eg your bank account.

##If your circumstances change

Tell the Carer's Allowance Unity if your circumstances change as this can affect how much you get. Examples of changes include:  income, employment, holidays or stays in hospital. 

You can do this [online](http://www.dwp.gov.uk/carersallowance "Carer's Allowance e-service"){:rel="external"} or phone.

$C
**Carer's Allowance Unit**  
**Telephone**: 0845 608 4321    
**Textphone**: 0845 604 5312  
Monday to Thursday 8:30am to 5pm  
Friday 8:30am and 4:30pm  
$C  

^From April 2013 a limit will be put on the total amount of benefit that most people aged 16 to 64 can get. This is called a [benefit cap](/benefit-cap "benefit cap").^
table.title: What you'll get

table.body:
##Conditions -  you must meet 

You might get Carer's Allowance if you:

- are 16 or over
- spend at least 35 hours a week caring for someone
- have been in the UK or the Isle of Man for at least 26 weeks in the 12 months before you claim
- be in the UK when you claim - there are some exceptions, eg members and family members of the Armed Forces
- not be subject to immigration control

##Conditions - the person you care for

The person you care for must get one of these benefits:

- Attendance Allowance
- Disability Living Allowance - the middle or highest care rate
- Constant Attendance Allowance at or above the normal maximum rate with an Industrial Injuries Disablement Benefit
- Constant Attendance Allowance at the basic (full day) rate with a War Disablement Pension

^Use the [benefits adviser](/benefits-adviser "Benefits adviser") to check your eligibility.^

##Exceptions 

You may not get Carer's Allowance if:

- you're in full-time education (with at least 21 hours supervised study a week) or doing a full-time course
- you earn more than £100 a week (after tax)
- you get one of the benefits listed below

If you get any of the benefits below and they pay you £58.45 or more you may not get Carer's Allowance. Instead, Jobcentre plus wil work out if these benefits can be increased or you can now get other benefits.  

- Bereavement Allowance
- contribution-based Employment and Support Allowance
- contribution-based Jobseeker’s Allowance 
- Incapacity Benefit
- Industrial Death Benefit
- Maternity Allowance
- Severe Disablement Allowance
- State Pension
- training allowance
- Unemployability Supplement – paid with Industrial Injuries Disablement Benefit or War Pension
- War Widow’s or Widower’s Pension
- Widowed Mother’s Allowance
- Widowed Parent’s Allowance
- Widow’s Pension

##What you need to know 

Carer's Allowance can be backdated to the date of your claim. This is usually the date your form is received or the date you call the enquiry line (if you return the claim pack within 6 weeks). 

If someone else is looks after the same person, only one of you can get Carer's Allowance.

##Appeal a decision

You can appeal a decision about your Carer's Allowance if you're unhappy with it. 

$D
[Download 'Leaflet GL24,  Appeal against a benefit decision' (PDF, 4915KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@benefits/documents/digitalasset/dg_201702.pdf "Download 'Leaflet GL24, Appeal against a benefit decision' (PDF, 4915KB)"){:rel="external"}

table.title: How to claim

table.body:
##Effect on other benefits

Call the helpline for advice on how Carer's Allowance affects other benefits. 

$C**Benefit Enquiry Helpline**  
**Telephone:** 0800 88 22 00  
**Textphone:** 0800 24 33 55  
Monday to Friday 8:30am to 6:30pm
$C

##Your benefits 

If you get Housing Benefit or Council Tax Benefit you'll get extra towards these (called a 'carer premium'). 

if you get the following benefits you'll get extra Carer's Allowance, but these benefits are then reduced by that amount: 

- Income Support
- income-based Jobseeker's Allowance
- Pension Credit

##Your State Pension

Usually, for each week you get Carer's Allowance or the underlying entitlement you also get: 

+ [National Insurance credits](/boost-state-pension "National Insurance Credits")  
+ contributions to your [Additional State Pension](/additional-state-pension "Additional State Pension") 

Credits help to fill in any gaps in your National Insurance record. This can mean that you’ll still get the full State Pension and other benefits. These credits generally stop: 

+ in the tax year you reach State Pension age
+ if you get the underlying entitlement and Widow's Benefit or Bereavement Benefit

##The person you care for

Carer's Allowance can affect the person you care for, eg their: 

+ severe disability premiums
+ Pension Credit - severed disability element
